case_vignette: A 32-year-old G1P0000 presents to labor and delivery triage at 38 weeks gestation after several hours of contractions. Currently, they are timed about four minutes apart. Her contractions started after she tripped on a rug and fell on her side. She denies leakage of fluid and the baby has been moving normally, but she noted a small amount of blood on her underwear just before coming into the hospital. The pregnancy has been uncomplicated thus far. The patient has a past medical history of endometriosis, and this fetus was conceived by in vitro fertilization. Pelvic exam in triage reveals a cervix that is three centimeters dilated with a small amount of blood near the introitus. Fetal heart rate tracing at this time is shown in Figure A.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Understood, thank you. Have you experienced any vaginal bleeding or discharge during this pregnancy before?
No, the pregnancy has been uncomplicated without any prior bleeding or unusual discharge.
Okay, thank you for letting me know. Have you noticed any other symptoms such as cramping, back pain, or fever?

Please bear in mind that this examination is important for determining the cause of your contractions and ensuring the best possible care for you and your baby.

Can you please lift your legs up and lean back slightly, so I can access your pelvis?
All right, I'm in position as you've instructed.

Great, thank you. Now, I will insert a speculum into your vagina to visualize the cervix and vagina. This will help me to assess the size and position of the uterus, as well as to check for any abnormalities in the vaginal tissue.

Please let me know if you experience any discomfort or pain during the examination. I will make sure to keep the examination as comfortable as possible for you.

Is everything okay?

Great, thank you. I will now perform the ultrasound examination. Please keep your legs apart and your back supported to get the best images.

I will be looking for any signs of bleeding or abnormalities in the uterus or cervix. The examination should only take a few minutes.

Can you please hold your breath and remain still for a few moments while I take the images?

Thank you.

(After the examination)

Based on the results of the ultrasound, I believe you may be experiencing a threatened miscarriage. This can occur when the embryo is not developing properly and the placenta is not functioning adequately.

I would like to schedule you for a follow-up appointment in one week to monitor your condition and determine the best course of action. In the meantime, I recommend that you avoid any strenuous activities and take it easy to allow your body to rest and recover.

Do you have any questions or concerns about this diagnosis?

You're welcome! Yes, 38 weeks is quite advanced in pregnancy, so it's important to take any symptoms or concerns seriously. I'm glad you're taking the necessary steps to rest and recover.

Take care and feel better soon!
